body: Good point. Going on a trip, will address next week.
Hm, I was hoping to get this into Libgdx 1.0, but I know that is a short timeframe. Thanks though!
@badlogic sends me away on a trip, then just happens to pick that exact time to release 1.0. Something fishy is going on here...

This isn't precisely the issue I was submitting for, although that's definitely a fix. It was more why you call Gdx.gl.glViewport when you resize. My thoughts was that forces you to use the glViewport specified when you use a stage. Could that call just be removed? Or at least made a function that could be overridden (like updateViewport)? I know that's a hack, but I like to use multiple stages and this glViewport call is causing havoc. And as I said, the viewports should be virtual, not coupled to the actual OpenGL surface.

Well, I put in the update() because I had multiple viewports, but I thought it was ok to update the viewports outside of stage if an app needed to. All calls to Viewport#update are outside of stage, so you control when or if they are called. That ok?

I might be misunderstanding how the Viewports work, I guess. Since there isn't a way to resize a Stage without using the Viewport, it means if you have multiple stages then it becomes a question of fighting over glViewport between the glViewport you want and the ones the viewports are calling during a resize. 

I may be having problems because of this and the recent changes to the way that camera works now. Before I never had to do anything with glViewport because this was set when the app loaded, and then appeared to be updated in the engine before resize gets called, and all I had to do was update the Stages and my SpriteBatch to match the resize dimensions. Now it is cacophony...

My real question is why the call to glViewport, when in previous versions Stage.resize(w,h) didn't? At least not that I can find in the code...

If all your stuff uses the same glViewport, just update the Viewports in resize. If you have multiple stages that don't use the same glViewport then you need to call Viewport#update() to set glViewport before rendering each stage.
I will have to try that. For now I can't seem to get the viewport/stage changes to work correctly with the nightly branch, so I had to revert back to 0.9.9 for now. Thanks though.

The old stage always left the glViewport as the entire screen. The new viewport stuff may or may not use the entire screen for glViewport.

Viewport#update(*) calls glViewport (viewport A). Knowing that, if you want a different glViewport (viewport B) then you need to apply viewport B, draw using that, then apply viewport A using Viewport#update() and draw using that. Is there a problem doing this?

I understand, but my issue is not so much using a second Stage, as it is drawing without using a stage. The above examples use the default project bitmap (plus a few other bitmaps I added to make sure it wasn't something else I was doing wrong).

I suppose this becomes the crux of the problem. Your suggestion means that every render requires a call to glViewport, which seems wasteful. Although I have no idea how much time a glViewport change takes. 

If more of the internals of Viewport were available (such as designing ScalingViewport to be overridable), or different versions of Viewports available where the glViewport call is not done, then this would not be a problem.

But right now, if you use a Stage, then you are lashed to making a bunch of calls to glViewport if you aren't using a single Stage or drawing sprites outside of a stage. It seems inflexible compared to the previous Stage design.

If you use one viewport, the stage's viewport, then you call update in resize and draw, no every frame.

If you are using 2 viewports then you need to call glViewport twice per frame. There is no getting around this, it doesn't matter if Viewport#update calls glViewport or you do it manually, you still need to call it twice.

And example of an exception is the circumstance where you are using the camera to control the scaling, such as using two different batches with two different cameras. Camera A can be set to 1280x720 and Camera B can be set to 640x360. Then stage A would draw at the 1280x720 scale and stage B would draw at 640x360, correct? But if you use Viewport/Stage, then you must use glViewport.

There is also the issue that if you wanted to draw a bitmap as the clip for your game viewport, to emulate something like this:

![majestic twelve screenshot with bezel](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1960777/2857782/e63148bc-d17c-11e3-8b4f-d4011c3391cb.png)

You must use two stages or some combination of one stage and a call to glViewport.

I think at the very least that you could encapsulate the call to glViewport within Viewport.update (call it, say, updateViewport) and allow end users of libgdx to override that function to remove that call if desired. Another perhaps better option is to have the rest of the update function encapsulated in a call something like updateCamera(). Then if scaling in ScalingViewport were protected (or you added a function called getScaling(screenWidth, ScreenHeight) ), then you could make your own custom viewport that behaves in ways that are more efficient when using Stages or drawing bitmaps in tandem with stages.

I think there are many ways around the problem, but the current codebase doesn't support them.

My point is only that the current stage design eliminates hybrid implementations. My workflows usually implement UI elements with a Stage that is scaled to the dimensions of the window, but I have my own entities that do not use a stage (example: Box2D based objects) to render. Using a Stage with libgdx 1.0.0 precludes that behavior.

If you have 2 stages with the same glViewport, it doesn't matter that Viewport#update() calls glViewport and you only need the glViewport set in resize(). You only need to call glViewport or Viewport#update() in your render loop if you have 2 or more different glViewports. You can have any number of cameras set to scale differently.

I disagree. You also need to call glViewport twice if your Stage Viewport is different dimensions from the window, as well. That's what my above example shows with StretchViewport. That is only using one stage.

Or to maybe be more clear, if you do not have the call to glViewport in Viewport, then the above example never needs to call glViewport. The viewport is the window dimensions, and the stage stretches to fit the window.

Maybe I can be more convincing by saying that you are unnecessarily coupling the dimensions of the Stage to the glViewport (much less the Viewport). I understand that a Stage may not need the whole viewport, but why link a logical structure like the Stage to a display feature like glViewport? Add in that  resizing a Stage ends up calling an OpenGL function in something that is not (at least to me) intuitively linked to the graphics section of libgdx like Camera, and I think it gets very confusing.

All I can say is that the dimensions and clip of the window should be something that is controlled in an obvious way, and making the Viewport clip in OpenGL makes fine sense to me from within Viewport itself. But intertwining that behavior with Stage is not efficient design to me.

I don't really understand your problem. Usually you always want the same behaviour for all your viewports. That means that they will all call `glViewport()` with the same parameters and there's no problem.

In that one picture that you posted, with a picture as the "black bars", you'd still have the same viewports everywhere. Then when you drew everything, you'd do a `glViewport(0, 0, Gdx.graphics.getWidth(), Gdx.graphics.getHeight())` and then query the viewports for their "`gutter width/height`". After you did that, you'd `update` them again, to set the "usual" glViewport.

I cannot think of any scenario where you'd actually have several different viewports where they might anyhow interfere with each other.

> I understand that a Stage may not need the whole viewport, but why link a logical structure like the Stage to a display feature like glViewport?

The glViewport matters to stage because it affects how inputs are mapped from screen coordinates. See [project/unproject](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/utils/viewport/Viewport.java#L77) methods.

Once you understand the Viewport applies glViewport, it shouldn't be a problem to call `Viewport#update()` to change the glViewport as needed. This will be once in `resize` if you have a single glViewport, or if you have multiple, once before each rendering of a different viewport.

I guess I am unable to communicate the problem. I just think that Stage
should be logical. You set the dimensions of the viewport and set the
stages dimensions and positions and render to the camera (which is the old
way), without regard to the actual OpenGL viewport.

The way the code is now, the stage is forced to be the size of the
viewport, and there can only be one viewport. To me this doesn't make
sense, because it means you can't have or at least are making it hard to
have multiple stages. So if you want one stage for text rendered at the
resolution of the window, and another at your game scale for sprite actors,
you cannot with libgdx without calling glViewport manually.

If you don't set the glViewport to match the stage's viewport, drawing the stage would (could) overflow the given area.

As for not being able to use more than one viewport, stage, or whatever - that is just not accurate. I do exactly that with no trouble.

I didn't mean to imply you couldn't have multiple stages or viewport, in
fact my example uses multiple stages. The issue is that a given stage is
coupled to a viewport, which forces you to use multiple Viewport objects
meaning you end up with multiple calls to glViewport. I believe this is
unnecessary, not impossible to do.
